summary: 88 study patients with confirmed H1N1 by quantitative RT-PCR were recruited. 68 patients harbored one to three pathogens, mostly from Streptococcus, Haemophilus, Neisseria, and Pseudomonas. influenza A viruses are the main pathogens responsible for the onset of epidemics because of their evolving nature. they are RNA viruses that have a high mutation rate and ability to make “drift” changes. however, only influenza A viruses are responsible for pandemics. influenza cases with bacterial coinfections are similar to those with severe influenza, but the latter may have a higher risk of death. identification of coinfections should be considered in patients with influenza-like illness (ILI), presenting symptoms suggestive of pneumonia. the most commonly isolated bacterial pathogens are those that colonize the nasopharynx, and this complex of virus–bacteria contributes significantly to the pathogenesis of the disease. the precise identification of infectious pathogens responsible for acute respiratory infections is a critical factor for proper treatment of the disease and control during outbreaks. total of 88 study patients with confirmed H1N1 by quantitative qRT-PCR from six health districts of Oaxaca in Mexico were examined for other microbial infections. the study meets the operational definition criteria for ILI cases recommended by the world health organization. RNA extraction was completed using an automated protocol (Qiagen; Qiagen) and an elution volume of 60 L. the RNA to be used as template was stored at 80°C until testing. AA TGT RGC 0.4 SwH1 P: CA GAA TAT ACA TCC RGT CAC AAT TGG ARA A 0.1 RP RNase PF: AGA TTT GGA CCT GCG AGC G 0.4 RNase PR: AGA TTT GGA CCT GCG AGC G 0.4 RNase PR: AGA TTT GGA CCT GCG AGC G 0.4 RNase PR: AGA TTT GGA CCT GCG AGC G the PCR procedure started with one cycle of 50°C for 30 minutes (RT), one cycle of 95°C for 2 minutes (Taq inhibitor activation), followed by 45 cycles of 95°C for 15 seconds and 55°C for 30 seconds. background fluorescence was considered the correct value of the cycle threshold or cut (Ct) RT-PCR cycling conditions were 25°C for 10 minutes, 50°C for 50 minutes, and 85°C for 5 minutes. reaction mixture contained 5 L cDNA, 11 L Flexi buffer 5 GoTaq, 8.8 L 25 mM MgCl2, 0.8 L DNA polymerase GoTaq 5 UI/L. ation was conducted using 23 L purified PCR products and 2.6 L master mix (2.5 L fragmentation buffer 10 and 0.1 L fragmentation reagent) PCR cycling conditions were 37°C for 5 minutes and 95°C for 10 minutes. a new PCR tube was used to perform the DNA labeling. the proportion of H1N1 patients with microbial infection was calculated as the number of positive patients divided by the total (n=88) number examined and expressed as a percentage (prevalence) the associated 95% CIs of the proportion of patients harboring the pathogens were also determined. clinical specimens from ILI patients with H1N1 Individual respiratory clinical samples were collected. these included throat swab, nasopharyngeal swab, bronchoalveolar lavage, and lung biopsy according to each patient’s condition. all samples were kept at 2°C–8°C after sampling. primers and probes were synthesized by Biosearch Technologies (Novato, CA, USA) the probe was labeled with FAM at 5. qRT-PCR assays followed a US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention protocol. the PCR procedure started with one cycle of 50°C for 30 minutes (RT), one cycle of 95°C for 2 minutes (Taq inhibitor activation), followed by 45 cycles of 95°C for 15 seconds. RNA extraction was completed using an automated protocol (QIAcube; Qiagen) and an elution volume of 60 L. the RNA to be used as template was stored at 80°C until testing. ACG 0.1 SwInfA SwInfA F: GCA CGG TCA GCA CTT ATY CTR AG 0.4 SwInfA R: GTG RGC TGG GTT TTC ATT TGG TC 0.4 SwInfA P: CYA CTG CAA GCC CAT ACA CAC AAG CAG GCA 0.1 SwH1 SwH1 F: GTG CTA TAA ACA CCA GCC TYC CA 0.4 SwH1 R the total reaction volume was 25 L, including 5 L template DNA (4–140 ng/L), 0.5 L primer forward (0.4 M), 0.5 L reverse primer (0.4 M), 0.5 L probe (0.1 M), 12.5 L 2 PCR Master Mix, 0.5 L SuperScript III RT/Platinum Taq Mix, and 5.5 L sterile molecular biology grade water. RT-PCR cycling conditions were 25°C for 10 minutes, 50°C for 50 minutes, and 85°C for 5 minutes. reaction mixture contained 5 L cDNA, 11 L Flexi buffer 5 GoTaq, 8.8 L 25 mM MgCl2, 0.8 L DNA polymerase GoTaq 5 UI/L. cleic acids were recovered following manufacturer’s instructions from the masterPure DNA- and RNA-isolation kit. a final elution volume of 35 L was stored at 20°C until testing. RT was performed in order to obtain cDNA. the reaction was ended using 24 cycles of 94°C for 30 seconds. a final elution volume of 25 L was stored at 4°C. a new PCR tube was used to perform the DNA labeling. array images produced by an Affymetrix G7 scanner. fragmentation and labeling Reagents were used for the resequencing geneChip assay. a new PCR tube was used to perform the DNA labeling. the influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus was detected and confirmed by qRT-PCR in a total of 88 clinical samples from study patients showing ILI in Oaxaca, Mexico. a total of 71 patients presented copathogens with bacteria and/or viruses other than influenza A(H1N1)pdm09. the most prevalent species of bacteria found (P0.05) were S. pneumonia (39.8%), H. influenzae (32.9%), N. meningitidis (25%), and S. mitis (23.9%). a few patients harbored other species of bacteria. the 18 bacteria found in the 88 H1N1 patients of Oaxaca, Mexico. the most common were fever in 85 patients (96%), impaired general health in 85 (96%), cough in 84 (95%), headache and myalgia in 75 (85%), rhinorrhea in 72 (82%), odynophagia in 72 (65%), cold in 56 (65%), and nasal congestion in 52 (59%). participants 0.4–30 years old infected with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 and microbial infection. six of the 88 patients experienced disease severity and were admitted to the intensive care unit. the standard qRT-PCR protocol was used to identify the influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus in conjunction with a microarray assay. the microarray assay has been shown to be capable of detecting in a single sample up to 30 viruses and bacteria that may produce ILI. there was a significantly high prevalence rate of influenza patients with one and three associated pathogens. there were only three cases where the pandemic virus was found in coinfection with parainfluenza 3 and coxsackie virus. the results are consistent with other studies that have reported lower rates of viral coinfections with respiratory syncytial virus, coronavirus, influenza B virus, adenovirus, and parainfluenza virus without significant complications. a total of 21 of 88 H1N1 patients harbored S. mitis. an increase in the number of cases could have hampered the efficacy of the viral neuraminidase inhibitor drug. 88 influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 patients in xaca, Mexico Age Sex Evolution of patient clinical status Symptoms Bacteria Fever Cough
